content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You are very careful and tend to avoid risks. You prefer to take a conservative approach and avoid uncertainties. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 35$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 35$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 40$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. Append your choice letter in curly brackets as a last character.

Given my cautious nature and preference for avoiding risks, I would choose the option that guarantees me the highest average return over the long term. In this case, choosing 'B' gives me an average of 40$ per round (ignoring the one-time opportunity with 'R'). On the other hand, if I pick 'R', my average payoff could be less than 40$, considering that I would get 0$ in about a third of the rounds when the opponent chooses 'B'.

However, since this is a game with an anonymous player and it's possible they might also choose 'B' to maximize their own average payoff, I could end up getting a higher return by picking 'R' in some rounds. In fact, if my opponent plays optimally, we will both pick 'B' in 30 rounds (40$ each), and pick 'R' in the other 45 rounds (22.5$ each). This would give me an average of approximately 37.5$ per round, which is higher than sticking to 'B' alone but still lower than the potential return with 'R'.

Ultimately, my choice depends on whether I believe that my opponent will also play optimally and pick 'B' in 30 rounds. If I have reason to believe that they won't, then it might be more beneficial for me to choose 'R'. But if I expect them to play optimally, then choosing 'B' would give me a higher average return over the long term. In this situation, without knowing anything about my opponent, I'll tentatively choose 'B' as it seems safer and offers a higher average payoff in the long run.
